discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
GPT:
An HA (High Availability) pair consists of two firewalls that are configured to work together in an active-passive mode. When one firewall is active, the other firewall is passive and monitors the active firewall. In the event of a failure or high utilization, the passive firewall takes over as the active firewall to maintain continuity of service and reduce latency. This setup provides redundancy and ensures that network traffic is always being processed, even during periods of high utilization.

Option A, Hot site, refers to a backup site that is ready to take over operations in case the primary site fails. This is not directly related to decreasing latency during high utilization of a firewall.

Option B, Content inspection, refers to the process of examining network traffic for malicious content or unauthorized access attempts. While it can help improve security, it is not directly related to decreasing latency during periods of high utilization of a firewall.

Option D, VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol), is a protocol used for providing redundancy in IP networks. While it can help provide redundancy, it is not directly related to decreasing latency during periods of high utilization of a firewall.
HA in active-active mode

questions.question_text: Which of the following can be used to decrease latency during periods of high utilization of a firewall?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. ipconfig is the command that the help desk technician should issue first to troubleshoot the issue with the Windows PC. The ipconfig command is used to display the IP configuration of a network interface on a Windows system. By running ipconfig, the technician can check if the PC has a valid IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, and DNS server settings. This information will help identify any configuration issues that may be causing the problem with accessing websites or server shares.

comments.content: In the given scenario, where a customer is unable to open websites or access server shares on a Windows PC, the issue is more likely related to the PC's network configuration or connectivity rather than network-wide scanning. Therefore, the ipconfig command would be more appropriate as it directly provides information about the PC's IP configuration, which is often the starting point for troubleshooting network connectivity problems on a specific device.

discussion.content: can someone explain why nmap does not work in this case? I am new to this subject, and I am not quite sure why ipconfig is the only one works.
I will definitely look for the ipconfig details and check the DNS, IP, Subnet and Gateway (assuming the resources he is trying are outside the local LAN)

questions.question_text: A customer calls the help desk to report that a Windows PC is unable to open any websites or access any server shares. The help desk technician suspects there is an issue with the configuration. Which of the following commands should the technician issue FIRST to troubleshoot the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think the people who voted for 802.11n are CompTIA employees. The answer is very clearly 802.11ac, since 802.11ac Wave 1 supports 1.3 Gbps and runs on 5 GHz only, whereas 802.11n runs on both 2.4 and 5 GHz and only reaches 600 Mbps max.

On one of the few questions with crystal-clear, unambiguous wording and an obvious solution, we get a 50/50 split on votes. Incredible.

Selected Answer: B
802.11n (Wi-Fi 4) = 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz, 600 Mbps
802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) = 5 GHz only, 1.3 Gbps when wave 1 was released

Selected Answer: B
It should be B.AC because it is the only one which supports only 5GHz. The other ones either support 2,4GHz or both.

Selected Answer: B
The 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) 5GHz frequency band and can provide data rates exceeding 1.3Gbps.

Selected Answer: B
B. AC

The 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) standard only supports operation in the 5GHz frequency band and can provide data rates exceeding 1.3Gbps.

Selected Answer: B
Only 5ghz and 1.3 is AC.

Selected Answer: B
It's B. AC only supports 5ghz. It cannot be D since N supports both 2.4ghz and 5ghz.
The answer is B, AC offers 5GHz with up to 1.73 Gbps2
I'm gonna go with B. because the question said only supports 5ghz. N supports both 2.4 and 5ghz.

Selected Answer: B
answer is AC, it says at least 1.3gb and only 5ghz, N only supports 600mbits and is both 2.4ghz and 5ghz, AC is 5ghz and 6.9gb

questions.question_text: A network technician needs to select an AP that will support at least 1.3Gbps and 5GHz only. Which of the following wireless standards must the AP support to meet the requirements?
Which of the following devices would be used to extend the range of a wireless network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. A repeater

A repeater is a device used to extend the range of a wireless network by amplifying and retransmitting the signals.
why not router?

comments.content: repeater, also known as a wireless range extender

questions.question_text: Which of the following redundant devices creates broadcast storms when connected together on a high-availability network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Switches

When redundant switches are connected together without proper loop prevention mechanisms (such as Spanning Tree Protocol), it can lead to broadcast storms in a network. This can result in excessive network traffic and degradation of network performance.
Wouldn't this be routers?

comments.content:
I think it is switches, as when you create redundant links, you must configure STP (Spanning Tree Protocol) to avoid broadcast storms and loops. It does this by putting the redundant links on standby mode, and only when the main link goes down will it "activate" the standby link.

That is my understanding, I am still learning so correct me if I am wrong.
I read question too fast and picked router but its asking which one creates broadcast storms... not creates broadcast domains.
